instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power But S0 Rails Pulse
threads.message: Hello. Got this board here initially with no power at all. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> was stuck on 1.6V. After inspection I found corrosion around <CAPACITOR>C2952</CAPACITOR> area. Cleaned everything and replaced all caps that looked bad and also <CHIP>U8000</CHIP> that was shorted to GND. Now board gets steady 8.56V on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and tries to enter S0. All S0 coils pulse including L7310/20 but after that it goes to 0V again and nothing else. Already inspected whole board for other corrosion points but could not find anything. Where should I look now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power But S0 Rails Pulse
threads.message:
Check all SPI Bus Series Termination resistors and their traces.
Be sure <CHIP>U6101</CHIP> has good solders.
You may need to clean/remove J6100.

Do you get two pulses on the coils, or power cycling?
Just in case, try to start in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power But S0 Rails Pulse
threads.message: Hello. I get 2 pulses and then 0V on S0 coils. All SPI resistors read OK. Re-soldered <CHIP>U6101</CHIP> just in case and removed J6100. When in SMC bypass I get quarter fan.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power But S0 Rails Pulse
threads.message:
Possibly accumulated crap underneath CPU.
Heat it to 180-200 degrees, no more than 15-20s.

May need to reball SMC also.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power But S0 Rails Pulse
threads.message: Heated CPU for some seconds with original Amtech flus on 200 degrees and reballed SMC. Same thing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power But S0 Rails Pulse
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power But S0 Rails Pulse
threads.message: I decided to throw it into US Cleaner to see if there was any crap under big chips. Now after cleaning and drying it up the board is a little different. Now it seems it's power cycling. No fan spin nor quarter fan spin but CPU coils keep pulsing like if it's trying to turn on. <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> seems to pulse also.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power But S0 Rails Pulse
threads.message:
Very likely CPU problem.
Did you try SMC bypass again?
